entries.meaning: comparative form of broke: more broke

description: From Middle English broker, brokour, brocour, from Anglo-Norman brocour (“small trader”) (compare also abroker (“to act as a broker”)), from Old Dutch *brokere (“one who determines the usages of trade, manager”), from broke, bruyck, breuck (“use, usage, trade”), from Proto-West Germanic *brūkī (“use, custom”), from Proto-Germanic *brūkiz (“use, custom”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰruHg- (“to use, enjoy”), equivalent to brook +‎ -er.

entries.meaning: A mediator between a buyer and seller.
examples: Hyponyms: playbroker, power broker, stockbroker, pawnbroker, floor broker, honest broker, money broker, piece broker, produce broker, sworn broker

entries.meaning: A mediator in general, one who liaises between two or more parties to attempt to achieve an outcome of some kind.
(computing) An agent involved in the exchange of messages or transactions.
examples: Hyponyms: message broker, object request broker, storage resource broker, tunnel broker

verbs.description: broker (third-person singular simple present brokers, present participle brokering, simple past and past participle brokered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To act as a broker; to mediate in a sale or transaction.
(transitive) To act as a broker in; to arrange or negotiate.
